title: R45254
content: The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds independent agencies in Title V, which manage federal property, regulate financial institutions, and oversee mail delivery. The bill also covers general provisions in Title VII and Cuba sanctions in Title I, along with funding for the Department of the Treasury, Executive Office of the President, and judiciary. The Financial Services and General Government (FSGG) appropriations bill funds various agencies including the Executive Office of the President, judiciary, and District of Columbia. It focuses on mandatory retirement accounts and general provisions for FSGG agencies. The bill also addresses financial regulation issues in additional titles but does not fund many financial regulatory agencies. The current form of the FSGG bill has been in place since the 2007 reorganization of the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations. The House and Senate FSGG bills fund various agencies, including the CFTC. President Trump's FY2018 budget requested approximately $3.1 billion for independent agencies, with $330 million allocated to the CFTC. The House Committee on Appropriations reported the Financial Services and General Government Appropriations Act, 2018 (H.R. 3280, H.Rept. 115-234) on July 18, 2017. The bill included $253 million for FSGG independent agencies and $248 million for the CFTC in the Agriculture appropriations bill (H.R. 3268, H.Rept. 115-232). The total funding of $501 million was significantly lower than the President's FY2018 request, with most of the difference in GSA funding. Division D of H.R. 3354 included most of H.R. 3280 when considered by the House of Representatives on September 6, 2017. The House of Representatives considered H.R. 3354 on September 6, 2017, amending the bill multiple times. Funding for FSGG independent agencies totaled $488 million after amendments, with decreases in GSA funding and increases in SBA funding. The bill passed the House on September 14, 2017. The Senate Committee on Appropriations released a recommended FSGG draft bill on November 20, 2017, with funding totaling $593 million, $2.5 billion below the President's FY2018 request. The House of Representatives passed H.R. 3354 with amendments, resulting in $488 million funding for FSGG agencies. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended a draft bill with $593 million funding, $2.5 billion below the President's FY2018 request. Congress passed H.R. 601 / P.L. 115-56, providing continuing appropriations through December 8, 2017, with anomalies focusing on decreasing funding for the presidential transition. The presidential transition funding was increased in FY2017 with four additional CRs enacted in December 2017, January 2018, and February 2018. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 was enacted on March 23, 2018, with additional funding for the GSA and SBA to address disaster costs from hurricanes in 2017. The FY2018 enacted appropriations for FSGG agencies totaled $4.7 billion, $1.6 billion above the original request. The funding included emergency funding for the SBA. The GSA, FCC, and Election were also mentioned in the appropriations. The FY2018 appropriations for FSGG agencies totaled $4.7 billion, with emergency funding for the SBA. The GSA, FCC, and EAC also had significant funding differences between requested and enacted amounts. Table 1 and Table 2 provide details on the status of FSGG appropriations measures and the amounts requested and enacted for FY2018. The FSGG appropriations bill provides funding for independent agencies overseeing various functions. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission regulates derivatives markets. The Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) is responsible for overseeing derivatives markets, including futures exchanges and swaps markets. Its functions include registration and supervision of industry personnel, prevention of fraud and price manipulation, and investor protection. Congressional authorization jurisdiction remains with the House and Senate Agriculture Committees due to the market's historical origins. Following the financial crisis of 2008, reforms in the Dodd-Frank Act brought previously unregulated over-the-counter swaps markets under CFTC jurisdiction. This expanded the CFTC's oversight to include futures, options, and economically significant swaps. The Dodd-Frank Act expanded CFTC oversight to include swaps markets with a $240 trillion notional value in the US. The CFTC also oversees futures and options markets with a $34 trillion notional value. Funding for the CFTC in FY2018 was $249 million. The Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) is a federal agency focused on reducing consumer harm from various products. It sets safety standards, collaborates with industries, bans unsafe products, monitors recalls, educates consumers, conducts research, and collects data on product hazards. It also works with state and local governments to establish uniform regulations. The Trump Administration requested $123 million in appropriations for the Consumer Product Safety Commission (CPSC) in FY2018, $3 million less than FY2017. The reduction included cuts to the Virginia Graeme Baker Pool and Spa Safety Act's grant program and salaries/expenses due to a decrease in full-time employees. The CPSC's budget request would be allocated among four strategic goals. The Trump Administration requested $123 million for the CPSC in FY2018, with allocations for workforce development, product safety, hazard response, and communication. $1.3 million was designated for new VGBPSA grants against the Administration's wishes. The House Appropriations Committee expects the CPSC to maintain the FY2017 level of grant funding in FY2018 at $1.3 million. The committee advised against adopting two proposed rules, one on voluntary recalls for small firms and the other on public disclosure of product hazards. The bill included two administrative provisions, one of which would prevent the CPSC from finalizing a proposed rule on recreational off-highway vehicle safety until a study by the National Academy of Sciences is completed. The Senate draft bill allocated $123 million for the CPSC, while P.L. 115-141 provided $126 million for the CPSC. Section 502 aimed to halt the finalization of a rule on blade saw injuries. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to provide grant funding for election reform programs and voting machine certification. The Election Assistance Commission (EAC) was established under the Help America Vote Act of 2002 to oversee election issues, voting systems standards, and grant funding for election reform programs. The EAC does not have new rulemaking authority under HAVA, but it took over responsibilities for the National Voter Registration Act from the Federal Election Commission. The Department of Justice enforces HAVA, and the President's FY2018 budget requested $9.2 million for the EAC, with $1.5 million allocated to the National Institute of Standards and Technology for voting testing guidelines. The EAC received funding from H.R. 3354 and P.L. 115-141, with $1.5 million allocated to NIST for election reform activities. The Senate draft bill proposed $9.2 million for the EAC. Additionally, $380 million was appropriated for improving election administration. The FCC is an independent agency with five members appointed by the President. The FCC is a federal agency established in 1934 to regulate interstate and international communications by radio, television, wire, satellite, and cable. Its budget is funded through regulatory fees collected from license holders and other entities, rather than through direct appropriation. The FCC has the authority to review and adjust these fees annually. The FCC requested a budget of $322 million for FY2018, derived from regulatory fees. The House and Senate bills both appropriated $322 million, with a cap for spectrum auction administration. P.L. 115-141 also included $600 million for the TV broadcaster relocation fund. The FDIC is funded through deposit insurance funds. The FDIC's Office of the Inspector General (OIG) is funded through deposit insurance funds, with $39.1 million appropriated in FY2018 for auditing and reviewing operations. This amount was approved in H.R. 3354 and P.L. 115-141. The FDIC OIG received $39.1 million in funding in FY2018. The FEC is an independent agency that enforces campaign finance regulations and administers the presidential public financing system. The agency requested $71.25 million for FY2018, which was included in H.R. 3354. The FEC requested $71.25 million for FY2018, which was included in H.R. 3354. An additional $7.9 million was appropriated in FY2017 for the FEC's office space lease. The agency is scheduled to move to a new location in FY2018. Approximately 90% of the agency's budget is expected to fund salaries, benefits, IT, and facilities expenses. Other sections of the FSGG legislation contained provisions related to campaign finance policy. The House-passed version includes provisions prohibiting SEC rules on political contribution disclosure, enforcing a FECA provision on trade association solicitation, and reporting political contributions for government contracts. P.L. 115-141 allocated $71.25 million for the FEC. The enacted law included provisions from the House-passed version, allocating $71.25 million for the FEC. The Federal Trade Commission's primary responsibilities are to protect consumers and maintain competition by enforcing laws and educating stakeholders. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) is responsible for issuing regulations, educating consumers and business owners, and ensuring competition in markets. The agency's funding comes from direct appropriations, premerger filing fees, and Do-Not-Call Registry fees. In FY2017, direct appropriations accounted for 53.3% of the FTC's budget. In FY2018, the FTC's budget request included $178.6 million in direct appropriations, $112.7 million in HSR filing fees, and $15 million in DNC registry fees, totaling $306.3 million. This was $6.7 million less than the FY2017 enacted amount, with a $5 million cut in salaries and expenses due to a projected decrease in full-time staff. H.R. 3354 as passed by the House would have appropriated $164.3 million in direct appropriations, $126 million from HSR filing fees, and $16 million from DNC registry fees for the FTC in FY2018. The House Appropriations Committee directed the FTC to report on enforcing privacy laws for consumer information collected by internet service providers. The committee also requested a report on the benefits of credit education services and the impact of the Credit Repair Organizations Act on new products and technology. The Senate draft bill would have appropriated $306.3 million. The Senate draft bill allocated $306.3 million for the FTC, with funding from various sources. The General Services Administration oversees federal procurement policies and manages federal property and records, including facilities for former Presidents. The General Services Administration (GSA) manages funding and facilities for former Presidents and presidential transitions through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF). The FBF is funded by rental payments from federal agencies leasing GSA space, with Congress allocating funds for specific activities like construction, repairs, and rental payments. GSA must adhere to limitations set by Congress for FBF funds. The General Services Administration (GSA) manages funding for former Presidents and presidential transitions through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF). GSA must adhere to Congress-set limitations on FBF funds, which cannot exceed the permitted amount regardless of available revenue. A negative FBF total occurs when funds available for expenditure are less than expected revenue, indicating a net gain to the fund. GSA's operating accounts are funded separately from the FBF. The General Services Administration manages funding for former Presidents and presidential transitions through the Federal Buildings Fund (FBF). The President proposed a limit of $9.951 billion for GSA's real property activities in FY2018, an increase of $1.106 billion from FY2017. The House-passed bill included a limit of $7.842 billion, a decrease of $1.003 billion from FY2017. The Senate draft bill proposed a limit of $7.809 billion for GSA's real property activities in FY2018, which was $1.036 billion less than the FY2017 enacted amount and $2.142 billion less than the President's request. P.L. 115-141 provided a limit of $9.074 billion, an increase of $229 million from FY2017 and $877 million less than the President's request. The President also requested $511 million for GSA's operating accounts, an increase of $257 million from FY2017. The President's FY2017 request included funding for the Asset Proceeds and Space Management Fund (APSMF) and the Environmental Review Improvement Fund to carry out actions related to public buildings reform and environmental review process reform. The President requested $228 million for a new Technology Modernization Fund to improve agency IT systems. The House-passed bill allocated $240 million for GSA's operating accounts, $14 million less than FY2017 levels. The Senate draft bill proposed $234 million for GSA's operating accounts, $20 million less than FY2017 levels. P.L. 115-141 provided $335 million in funding. The enacted FY2018 appropriations for GSA's operating accounts were $335 million, which was $81 million more than FY2017 and $176 million less than the President's request. Additionally, an emergency supplemental appropriation of $127 million was included in response to recent disasters. The FSGG appropriations bill also included funding for agencies with personnel management functions. The FLRA, an independent federal agency, administers Title VII of the Civil Service Reform Act of 1978, giving federal employees the right to join or form a union and bargain collectively over employment terms. The agency's funding amounts for FY2017, FY2018 requests, and enacted amounts from different bills are listed in Table 5. Employees have the right not to join a union representing their bargaining unit. Certain agencies are excluded by law, such as the FBI, CIA, GAO, NSA, TVA, FLRA, FSIP, and Secret Service. The FLRA consists of a three-member authority appointed by the President for five-year terms. The FLRA consists of a three-member authority appointed by the President for five-year terms. The authority resolves disputes over bargaining units, unfair labor practices, and representation elections. The General Counsel's office manages representation elections and investigates unfair labor practices. The FSIP resolves labor negotiation impasses between federal agencies and labor organizations. The President requested $26.2 million for the FLRA in FY2018. The FLRA would receive $26.2 million for FY2018, funding 121 FTEs. The MSPB, an independent agency, requested $46.8 million for FY2018 to fund 235 FTEs. The MSPB requested $46.8 million for FY2018 to fund 235 FTEs, citing the need to cover pay raises and IT infrastructure projects. The final appropriation was $46.8 million, as requested by the President. The President's budget requested $148.3 million for OPM salaries and expenses in FY2018, including funding for IT infrastructure modernization, acquisition workforce capacity strengthening, and trust fund transfers. The budget requested $131.4 million for trust fund transfers, $5 million for OIG salaries and expenses, and up to $25 million for OIG trust fund transfers for FY2018. OPM also requested an increase of 500 FTEs for FY2018 to address critical IT infrastructure needs and maintain security posture. The budget will enable OIG to continue oversight through audits and investigations. The OIG will continue oversight of agency programs, including the FEHBP and retirement trust fund programs, OPM financial statement, and IT infrastructure project. This includes audits, investigations, evaluations, inspections, prescription drug audit program, FEHBP claims data warehouse initiative, data center consolidation, and potential mainframe migrations. The House and Senate draft bills allocated appropriations for OPM salaries, trust fund transfers, and OIG expenses. The final appropriation was $129.3 million for OPM salaries, $131.4 million for trust fund transfers, $5 million for OIG expenses, and up to $25 million for OIG trust fund transfers. The OPM salaries amount was $19 million less than the President's request. H.R. 3354 required a report on OPM's data breach prevention efforts to be submitted within six months of enactment. The report accompanying H.R. 3280 evaluated OPM's cybersecurity policies, oversight of IT contractors, and compliance with government-wide cybersecurity initiatives. It included directives for OPM to modernize the federal retirement process. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize modernizing the federal retirement process and implementing a fully-automated electronic filing system. They also instructed OPM to enhance IT security measures, secure personally identifiable information, and continue upgrades to IT security for security clearance investigations. The House committee directed OPM to prioritize security clearance processing, expedite investigations, and provide progress reports on the NBIB implementation plan and costs. The OPM OIG must submit a report to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations within 12 months. The House committee directed OPM to assess the implementation of NBIB, staffing needs, performance issues, costs, governance structure, and make recommendations. OPM must prioritize security clearance processing and report on reducing barriers to recruitment by September 30, 2018. The House committee directed OPM to assess and make recommendations on reducing barriers to Federal employment and improving the recruitment process by September 30, 2018. Federal agencies are encouraged to increase recruitment efforts at Hispanic Serving Institutions and Historically Black Colleges and Universities. OPM is also directed to provide educational outreach and resources to federal agencies when filling critical positions. OPM was directed by the House committee to report on actions to improve hiring of CyberCorps graduates and acquisition planning within 90 days of the act's enactment. The Consolidated Appropriations Act, 2018 included directives for OPM cybersecurity. OPM is directed to provide updates on cybersecurity measures and modernization efforts, as well as address the retirement backlog. The House and Senate Committees on Appropriations expect OPM to complete outstanding GAO recommendations to enhance information security. OPM is directed to provide updates on cybersecurity measures, modernization efforts, and address the retirement backlog by reporting monthly progress to the House and Senate Committees on Appropriations. Mandatory appropriations for health benefits, life insurance, and retirement accounts were provided in H.R. 3354, the Senate draft bill, and P.L. 115-141. Congressional Budget Office estimated $13.2 billion for Government Payment for Annuitants and Employee Health. The Office of Special Counsel (OSC) is an independent federal agency focused on protecting federal employees from prohibited personnel practices. The President's budget requested $26.5 million for the OSC in FY2018, with an estimated FTE employment level of 144, an increase from the previous year. The agency's budget includes payments for annuitants, employee health benefits, life insurance, and the Civil Service Retirement and Disability Fund. The budget for the Office of Special Counsel (OSC) in FY2018 requested $26.5 million with an estimated FTE employment level of 144, an increase from the previous year. The funding was intended to meet rising demand for services, protect whistleblowers in the VA and other agencies, and manage increasing case levels. The National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) budget for FY2018 was requested at $376 million, which was $16 million less than the previous year. H.R. 3354 passed by the House included $380 million, while the Senate draft bill proposed $403 million. The National Credit Union Administration (NCUA) is an independent federal agency funded by credit unions. It manages the Community Development Revolving Loan Fund (CDRLF) to assist low-income credit unions in providing financial services to low-income communities. The CDRLF offers low-interest loans and deposits with repayment periods typically lasting five years. The CDRLF offers low-interest loans and technical assistance grants to low-income credit unions. Grants are available for improving operations and addressing safety and soundness issues. The President requested no money be appropriated for the CDRLF in FY2018, while H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill both proposed $2 million in appropriations. The Office of Government Ethics (OGE) is an independent federal agency established in 1978 with a $16.4 million budget for FY2018. OGE provides education and training on ethics in the executive branch, but does not investigate or prosecute ethics violations. The President requested $2 million for OGE, with the director appointed for a five-year term by the President with Senate confirmation. The President's request for OGE in FY2018 was $16.4 million, a $349,000 increase from FY2017. Both H.R. 3354 and the Senate draft bill allocated $16.4 million as requested. P.L. 115-141 appropriated the same amount. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) was initially established in 2004 and reconstituted as an independent agency in 2007. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) received its first funding as an independent agency in FY2009. Its role includes ensuring privacy and civil liberties are considered in anti-terrorism efforts, reviewing implementation of related laws and policies, and analyzing executive branch actions to protect the nation from terrorism while balancing privacy and civil liberties. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board (PCLOB) advises the President and executive branch on privacy and civil liberties issues. The President requested $8 million for the PCLOB in FY2018, which was appropriated in P.L. 115-114. The PCLOB, funded with $8 million from P.L. 115-114, oversees audits of public companies. The PCAOB, created by Sarbanes-Oxley, is funded through accounting fees. Sarbanes-Oxley also established a scholarship funded by PCAOB penalties for accounting students. The PCAOB oversees audits of public companies and funds a scholarship program for accounting students through monetary penalties. The Senate draft bill proposed allocating $1 million for scholarships from penalties collected by the Board. This funding was not included in the FY2018 Administration request or H.R. 3354. The SEC administers federal securities laws to protect investors and maintain fair trading markets. Its budget is set through appropriations, with fees collected from securities exchanges offsetting its funding. The SEC's budget is funded through fees collected from securities exchanges, which go directly to the Treasury Department. The agency must adjust its fees' rates to make its budget deficit-neutral. The President's FY2018 request for the SEC was $1.85 billion, with $245 million allocated for a new headquarters lease. H.R. 3354 passed by the House included $1.90 billion for the SEC in FY2018, while the Senate draft bill included $1.85 billion. Additionally, the Dodd-Frank Act established an SEC reserve fund for long-term expenses. The SEC reserve fund is funded by registration fees, with a limit of $50 million per fiscal year and a cap of $100 million. Excess funds go to the Treasury Department. In FY2017, $25 million was rescinded from the fund, and in FY2018, the President's request and the House's proposal aimed to rescind $25 million and $75 million, respectively. The Senate draft bill did not include any rescinded funds from the SEC. The Senate draft bill did not rescind funds from the SEC reserve fund, which was appropriated $1.90 billion in P.L. 115-141, with $245 million allocated for the headquarters lease. The Selective Service System (SSS) is an independent federal agency that operates under the Military Selective Service Act to fulfill emergency manpower needs of the military by conscripting personnel when directed by Congress and the President. Most males aged 18 through 25 in the United States are required to register with the SSS. Most males aged 18-25 in the US are required to register with the Selective Service System (SSS). The draft for military induction ended in 1973 and has not been reinstated. President Carter proposed standby draft registration for both men and women in 1980, but only male-only registration was approved by Congress. There is a possibility of including women in registration due to their eligibility to serve in combat roles. Funding for the SSS has remained stable in absolute dollars but has decreased when adjusted for inflation. The Small Business Administration (SBA) administers programs to assist small businesses, including loan guarantees, low-interest loans for disaster victims, training programs, and advocacy. Funding for SBA programs remained at $22.9 million for FY2018, the same as FY2017. The Small Business Administration (SBA) requested $829.1 million for FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loans, disaster assistance, and other programs. The Administration also requested authorization levels for loan guaranty programs. The Small Business Administration requested $829.1 million for FY2018, with allocations for salaries, entrepreneurial development, business loans, disaster assistance, and other programs. Authorization levels were requested for various loan guaranty programs, including $29.0 billion for the 7(a) program, $7.5 billion for the 504/CDC program, $4.0 billion for the SBIC program, and $12.0 billion for SBA-guaranteed trust certificates. The House-passed bill appropriated $862.8 million for the SBA for FY2018, with $260.0 million for salaries and expenses and $231.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs. The House-passed bill included a provision to increase Microloan intermediaries' spending limits on technical assistance grant funds. The Senate Committee on Appropriations recommended $886.3 million for the SBA for FY2018, $57.1 million more than the Administration's request, with $269.5 million allocated for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs. The SBA's final appropriation amount for FY2018 in P.L. 115-141 was $700.8 million, with $268.5 million for salaries and expenses, $247.1 million for entrepreneurial development and noncredit programs, and no funding for disaster assistance. The chairmen's recommended FSGG draft bill did not include the Microloan technical assistance provisions. The SBA received $1.66 billion in additional funding for disaster costs in FY2018. The USPS generates $69 billion annually from mail users. Congress provides annual appropriations to compensate USPS for revenue lost in providing free mailing privileges to the blind and overseas voters, authorized in the 1993 Revenue Forgone Reform Act. This act also allows for a $29 million annual reimbursement until 2035 to offset lost revenue from below-cost postal services during the phase-in period. The funds are deposited in the Postal Service Fund at the Department of the Treasury to cover USPS operating expenses. The Postal Accountability and Enhancement Act (PAEA) enacted in 2006 changed the postal appropriations process. Under the PAEA, USPSOIG and PRC must submit budget requests directly to Congress and OMB, funded from the Postal Service Fund. USPSOIG's budget is part of USPS's budget, while PRC's budget is separate. The PRC's budget, along with other independent regulators, is treated separately. In the FY2018 budget submission, the President requested $58.1 million for the Postal Service Fund, which is $23.4 million more than FY2017. The USPS also requested $71.3 million for FY2018, $36.7 million more than FY2017. H.R. 3354, Senate draft bill, and P.L. 115-141 all appropriated $58.1 million. In the FY2018 budget submission, the President requested $234.7 million for the USPSOIG, $19 million less than FY2017. The House-passed bill would have provided $234.7 million, while the Senate draft bill would have provided $245 million. P.L. 115-141 appropriated $245 million. The PRC and the President requested $14.4 million for FY2018. The PRC and the President requested $14.4 million for FY2018, which is about $1.8 million less than the PRC's FY2017 appropriation. H.R. 3354 as passed and the Senate draft bill would have provided the PRC with $15.2 million, which is $1 million less than the PRC's FY2017 appropriation and about $800,000 more than its FY2018 request. P.L. 115-141 provided the same $15.2 million. The House-passed bill included several long-standing postal policy provisions, such as requiring USPS to continue six-day mail delivery and providing mail for overseas voting and the blind free of charge. The House committee report directed the Postmaster General to submit a report on increasing sales of the Multinational Species semipostal stamp. The President's FY2018 budget request proposed extending long-standing appropriations policies, except for six-day mail delivery. The Trump Administration aims to implement reforms to reduce costs and improve USPS operations. The Trump Administration proposes reforms to reduce costs and improve revenue at USPS, including reducing mail delivery frequency, shifting to centralized and curbside delivery, and adjusting the rate structure. Changes to USPS's liabilities for retirement and retiree health benefits are also suggested. The Trump Administration proposes reforms to reduce costs and improve revenue at USPS, including changes to retirement and retiree health benefits. The President's FY2018 budget stated that these reforms would reduce the budget deficit by $46 billion over 10 years. P.L. 115-141 included policy provisions from the House-passed bill but did not enact further reforms as requested by the President. The United States Tax Court (USTC) is an independent judicial body with jurisdiction over tax matters under Article I of the Constitution. It was appropriated $51.2 million in FY2017, with varying amounts requested and appropriated in subsequent years. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes government-wide provisions. The FSGG Appropriations Act includes government-wide provisions, with new provisions proposed but not enacted for FY2018. If new budget authority exceeds the spending limit due to estimating differences, the OMB director will take action. The OMB director will adjust the FY2018 discretionary spending limit if there are estimating differences with CBO. The total adjustments cannot exceed 0.2% of the sum of all adjusted FY2018 limits. An alien authorized to work in the US under DACA would be eligible for federal government employment. The Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control administers Cuba embargo regulations, first issued in 1963. H.R. 3280 had provisions to tighten U.S. sanctions on Cuba, but they were not included in P.L. 115-141. Section 130 would have restricted funds from being used for property confiscated by Cuba. The provision aimed to prohibit the importation of rum and tobacco products by authorized U.S. travelers as accompanied baggage. It was similar to a provision in the House Appropriations Committee version of the FY2017 FSGG appropriations bill but was not included in the FY2017 enacted omnibus appropriations measure. Section 131 related to a trademark sanction on Cuba, prohibiting funds from authorizing licenses for marks, trade names, or property confiscated by Cuba. The provision aimed to prohibit OFAC from licensing payments for trademark registration fees related to a dispute over the Havana Club trademark between a Cuban company and Bacardi Limited. In January 2016, OFAC issued a specific license for the Cuban company to make payments for the renewal of the Havana Club trademark. The U.S. Patent and Trademark Office renewed the Havana Club trademark until 2026, following a provision that was not included in the final appropriations measure.
